<<<api>>>: HttpServlet
<<<code>>>: 
1. Create a static variable in the PushServlet class to hold the instance of the servlet:
   private static PushServlet instance;
   
2. Modify the constructor of the PushServlet class to assign the instance to the static variable:
   public PushServlet() {
       instance = this;
   }
   
3. Create a static method in the PushServlet class to retrieve the instance:
   public static PushServlet getInstance() {
       return instance;
   }
   
4. In your other classes, you can now access the PushServlet instance and call the enviarMensagem method:
   PushServlet pushServlet = PushServlet.getInstance();
   pushServlet.enviarMensagem(mensagem);
   
<<<explanation>>>: This approach uses a static variable to hold the instance of the PushServlet class. The constructor assigns the instance to the static variable, and a static method is provided to retrieve the instance. This allows other classes to access the PushServlet instance and call its methods, such as enviarMensagem. This way, any object in your application can send a message to the clients through the PushServlet.
